author: @arsyoubae5092
text:
Drake is an old man, he is god damn near 40, and he is being treated with kids gloves. He should do like Kendrick and go to therapy. How are you 37 and moving like a child. If he was a teen to maybe 30, I would understand, but he is grown. How has he, with all his riches, all his success, not figured out who he is yet? How is it that he is able to still not be authentic to himself? All I hear are excuses from Drake fans as to why he is the way he is, and yet nothing to show for it. Just emptiness and vapidness. Drake stands for nothing, yet weaponises everything - his blackness, his struggle with finding a place, his 'nice guy' persona. 

Drake is a weirdo, and, if all these artists who you put on no longer mess with you like that, why are you not self-reflecting on that. Why don't people want to be around you? What types of people are around you? This shows that Drake is not smart. He is not a deep thinker, he is not about the betterment of anything, let alone himself. He is literally everything that is wrong with the culture. He is fast food. Good in the moment, but adds nothing to your overall health.

Of course that doesn't mean that just because a person is Black doesn't mean that what they say is law or should be uncritically listened to or make them a monolith.

author: @brandonwintpoetry
text:
Two things I want to point out and/or celebrate:

- I really appreciated Antionette's clarity and patience in this discussion. Over and over, she was able to be both precise and nuanced in her articulations, particularly in the connections she was rendering between the cultural disdain some folks have for Drake, and his willingness to move in(to) whiteness for his own benefit. I appreciated her energy throughout. 

- I've only ever heard Marlon in the context of being a comedian or charismatic host. It was cool to see him bring this much insight and ease into a conversation that hinged upon cultural critique. 

 In general, I agreed with a lot of the points that were made about the particular cultural figure Drake is, and how hip-hop culture views him in this moment. I was really looking forward to this episode, and I wasn't disappointed by what you all offered.

author: @kayodesalandy
text:
Crazy work to want to sympathize with Drake "doing what he needs to do to fit into the culture that wouldn't accept him", but have issues with people using Drake's money and connections to build themselves up. If Drake is getting famous off of the ATL and TX culture, they should be allowed to get their lick back. Which is why I appreciate FD's point on the capitalism of it all since the "innovation" of capitalism is how it benefits from and upsets existing patterns of power, and they were all playing the game. "They culture vultured him" was crazier work though. Those with less power should absolutely be allowed to strip the carcass for all its worth.

But the thing I don't understand about Drake not fitting in is that we do like Drake with the melodies! Best I Ever Had IS a masterpiece. People keep referencing the Lil Wayne chat for Drake to keep it Aubrey. I can't remember whose point it was, but homegirl was right to call out Drake's tragicness of feeling unable to fit in. He made the choice to pursue capital.

Edit: I commented this before Antoinette asked how much are we willing to sell our culture for. Bars.

I think any true fan of something has probably gone through it - when what's being described of an artist or art form you love doesn't meet with your expectations or perception of that person or art form. There's a moment of dread as you try to reconcile these different  perceptions from reality and unsure where one begins and the other ends. 

Really great discussion. It's nice to see the passion everyone has, and also, I love yall setting boundaries and speaking up and saying "I'm not done talking" when others would jump in because yall are so passionate. Just really respectful and insightful discouurse all around. Thanks.

author: @bawnfriday
text: damn i wish some toronto rappers could have participated in this conversation. it feels like such a missed opportunity to talk about Black Canadian hip hop without addressing the industry we face, the colourism, the gatekeeping nonblack people do when it comes to funding Black art... Black people are 4.8% the population in Canada. We don't all feel desperate to "fit in" with Black Americans like Drake (whose immediate roots are from Memphis; he been disconnected from his OWN roots for a long time fr). Many of us are very comfortable making the music we make; we're just priced out the sector (also applies to anywhere else in Canadian entertainment industry too). If we do "make it", it's often because we collab with other artists from Jamaica or the USA. There is soooo much erasure that happens to Black Canadians that I wish got touched on more.

replies.author: @Owesomasaurus
replies.text:
Before this, the established pattern was K-Dot would release artistically profound albums that moved a decent number of units and would be beloved by backpackers, while Drake would make playlists that would do gigaton numbers and get the normies jumping.

So I think we can forgive anyone for thinking this would shake out in a similar way, with Kendrick putting out some lyrical miracle technical masterpiece while Drake dropped the no 1 jam of the summer.

So when Kendrick dropped a technical masterpiece, a harrowing therapy session *and* got the normies popping off with Not Like Us? Flawless victory.

replies.author: @Purple_Haz373
replies.text: @AllTheArtsyThe narrative that Kendrick was favored from the very beginning is a false one, and that bothered me from this panel. In Round 1, the panel spent an hour talking about how everyone counted Kendrick out: he took too long to drop a diss track; Drake was winning because ‚ÄúPush Ups‚Äù was great and Kendrick hadn‚Äôt dropped. Drake was everywhere! He had support from the industry. I traveled to New York, Atlanta, Chicago and saw Drake billboards everywhere I went! Drake was being promoted on the streams. He was being promoted by Ak, Mal, Adam and many in hip-hop media and entertainment. To assert that Drake was the underdog is quite frankly a lie out of the pit of hell. When people assert that Kendrick is an Industry Baby, it‚Äôs just simply untrue. No one was on Kendrick‚Äôs side. Even Kendrick fans doubted him and felt that he was never going to respond to Drake and many felt defeated and crowned Drake before ‚ÄúEuphoria‚Äù. Before Euphoria, everyone was talking shyt about Kendrick‚Äî-even after the great performance on ‚ÄúLike That‚Äù. People were still counting Kendrick out in the beginning, which is so baffling given that Kendrick is a far superior lyricist and rapper than Drake. So now, I see folk trying to change the narrative to claim that Kendrick was favored all along. That‚Äôs assertion is simply not true!

author: @whym6438
text:
So I'm not very far into the video, but I just got to the part where Zaid mentions Drake's B sharp bar, and I realized something about that.

There's a debate among musicians about whether that note exists at all (go look up Adam Neely's video about it), but let's say for the sake of argument that it does.


One of the things that people have been saying about Kendrick's A minor bar is that it's not just about kids - the double meaning is that the A minor scale uses only white keys on the piano, which ties it in to Drake's insecurity about his blackness. If you keep applying that logic about white and black keys, well, it's a bit of a stretch, but you could say that B sharp is a white key playing the role of a black key.

What I'm saying is, Drake dissed himself with that line.

replies.text: @Abdullah-vg1ucyou assuming that an artist wouldn‚Äôt take it that far is ignorant. In terms of double entendres, even triples, if nicki minaj can do it in each of her songs on every verse, then Kendrick can easily do it with this one, especially seeing how easy it is to make the correlation. Again, a minor on the piano are white keys, that line can easily be interpreted as a double entendre.
